column4: tico.. you dont understand I am not making a partition to install a new OS

I am just merely resizing my NTFS partition to give it a bit more room being I am running out.. I have 2 partitions.  1 NTFS of 10Gigs for Windows files. and The rest of the harddrive as a Fat32 partition.  I "took a chunk out of" the Fat32 parition giving me 3Gigs of freespace to use.  I unmounted the NTFS so I could resize it.  But when I go to resize it, it doesn't recognize the unformated space.
*yawns*
ask the question not just say "help" :P
you want to increase the size of the ntfs partition? Is the new space right next to the ntfs partition?
no
a partition cannot be fragmented it must be one block of hdd space
you can, but it must be directly after the ntfs partition
it must be (ntfs)(freespace)(fat32)
you need to move the fat32 partition into the free space
what do you mean move it into the 3Gig space?
yes
you must move the fat32 partition to provide room for the ntfs parittion to grow
move the fat32 partition so that there is room for the ntfs partition to grow
no, you're only moving it
gparted can move a partition
just move the current partition to the right
I don't think you can resize from the start of the partition, it's not trivial anyway
so use gparted
I haven't said anything that involves the terminal
I don't know where the exact buttons are or what they are called, but it should be obvious
make a backup
you have 3GB of space to move the fat32 partition into
which will make 3GB of free space after the ntfs partition
